headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fastenal Company Q4 and Fiscal Year 2014 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today'
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fastenal Company Q4 and Fiscal Year 2014 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ellen Trester of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Fastenal Company 2014 Annual and Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference call. This call will be hosted by Lee Hein, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Dan Florness, our Chief Financial Officer. Also present for today's call is Will
componenttext:
Welcome to the Fastenal Company 2014 Annual and Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference call. This call will be hosted by Lee Hein, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Dan Florness, our Chief Financial Officer. Also present for today's call is Will Oberton, our Chairman. The call will last for up to 45 minutes. The call will start with a general overview of our quarterly results and operations with Lee and Dan, with the remainder of the time being open for questions and answers. 
Today's conference call is proprietary Fastenal presentation and is being recorded by Fastenal. No recording where production transmission or distribution of today's call is permitted without Fastenal's consent. 
This call is being audio simulcast on the Internet via the Fastenal Investor Relations home page, investor.fastenal.com. A replay of the webcast will be available at the website until March 1, 2015 at midnight Central Time. 
As a reminder, today's conference call includes statements regarding the company's anticipated financial and operating results as well as other forward-looking statements based on current expectations as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements may often be identified with words such as we expect, we anticipate, upcoming or similar indications of future expectations. It is important to note that the company's actual results may differ materially from those anticipated. Information on factors that could cause results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements are contained in the company's priority filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and we encourage you to review those carefully. Investors are cautioned not to place undue reliance on such forward-looking statements as there is no assurance that the matter contained in such statements will occur. Forward-looking statements are made as of today's date only, and we undertake no duty to update the information provided on this call. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Lee Hein.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ellen. Good morning. Before I start, I'd like to just say thank you to the Fastenal members on the call. I know there's a lot of you that tuned into this, and we're so appreciative of the work that you did in the fourth quarter. So just a great jo
componenttext:
Thanks, Ellen. Good morning. Before I start, I'd like to just say thank you to the Fastenal members on the call. I know there's a lot of you that tuned into this, and we're so appreciative of the work that you did in the fourth quarter. So just a great job, and I'd like to report that it was a good quarter for our company, 13.8% sales growth, that's 15% -- or 15.7% on the daily average. and there's be some questions, I'm sure, on Christmas, and December was in line with the rest of the quarter. We just thought it was the right thing to do to take the 26th off. 20.1% on earnings growth, and that equated to 28% incremental margin growth, which again, these are strong numbers for our company. 
And how we got there really was we continued to work hard on our gross margin. But in this quarter, we really focused our attention on our expenses. And the Fastenal company and the members, I got to tell you, really did a nice job looking at all different types of expenses, and we really clamped down. 
And one thing that really came out is our ability to manage our labor. Historically, our daily average is going to decline somewhere around 10% from the end of October to the end of the year. We know that. And what we simply did is we turned down the hours or pulled back the hours and we looked at the timing of Thanksgiving, Christmas, et cetera, and just with the natural decline in our daily average. But we continue to add people at the company at part-time ranks. And I would say in 2015, with a good economy, we are committed to putting selling energy into our stores.  And I just, again, let me talk internally, we are committed to a store-based model. We are committed to the fact that we really believe being close to our customers, offering a high level of service is really the best way to really approach the industrial market. 
The other question we get is if you're going to add 10% to 15% more hours in the store, can you afford it? That really equates to about a 7% net effect on the labor dollar impact. And so it's a good model for us. It really bodes well for our stores and for most importantly, our customers. So strong quarter, we continued to stay disciplined on the gross margin. And there's pressure there, but we really like the momentum and the direction we are moving. With that, I'll turn it over to Dan.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lee, and good morning, everybody, and thanks again for participating in the call today.I think our press release is self-explanatory on the quarter. We published monthly numbers. And I think as Lee touched on, our sales trends remain strong t
componenttext:
Thank you, Lee, and good morning, everybody, and thanks again for participating in the call today.
I think our press release is self-explanatory on the quarter. We published monthly numbers. And I think as Lee touched on, our sales trends remain strong throughout the quarter, bode well as we go into 2015. I tried to highlight on the bottom Page 1, Page 2, a handful of bullets of things that I think were important to the business. One of them, I wanted to touch -- and some of these commentary is based on questions that I might get. And so I did want to touch on the headcount patterns as we were going through the fourth quarter, specially at the store level as we talked in the past about the investment in selling energy and adding hours. 
The one position we were in this year that we really weren't in last year is we are in a position to much more acutely manage the expense because we weren't in a ramp-up mode. We were in a manage-the-business mode. And so we did a much better job of managing our expenses in the fourth quarter. We were able to dial up and down the variable components of our expense, a big piece of that being store-based labor, to really match the needs of the business and really the needs of the customers to serve the customer. 
One item that I typically touch on or get questions on is the table we have on 'pathway to profit'. I think it's a good way to assess some of the underlying things going on in our business. And one of the things that is always helpful I think us appreciate how we look at our business. And one thing that we do is we're an organization that rewards our personnel internally, whether that be people at the store, at by the district level, in the distribution center or some other support roles. We reward folks based on our ability to grow the business. We reward more for growth sales than we do from maintenance sales, as an example. We reward for managing, containing the costs of our business and growing the profits of the business. So those are the things that really critical when we look at how we compensate. 
And so one thing to keep in mind when we look at that 'pathway to profit' table over the 3 years, because I always look at different buckets and my job is looking at 150,000-plus store or I look at the last 2 groups combined because they help me understand what's really going on in the business. And I am pleased to say when I look at 2014, I look at that group, the number of the -- the level of profitability, the components of the profitability make a lot of sense to me and position us well to go forward. One thing you'll notice is the profit in that group slipped slightly from a year ago. Now we're largely beyond the noise we've had in the past months, what's going on in gross margin year-over-year. So it's really about how are we managing expenses of the business and investing to grow the business. 
When I look at that slight leakage, what really drove it is a decision we made a year ago to dramatically expand our district and regional leadership. We went from roughly 230 district managers to shy of 300. We expanded the key accounts teams. We expanded our ability to manage the business and grow the business. 
The other thing that happens is if you look at the business this year, as Lee mentioned, we grew at 20.1%, our top line, 15.7% on daily, about 14% on an absolute basis. A year ago, those numbers were 9% pretax growth and about 7.5% sales growth. So what -- the other component of our P&L that changed dramatically is folks at the district level, folks at the regional level, our teams throughout the organization were paid a premium to grow our earnings. Bonuses and store compensation were up meaningfully from a year ago. And so when I look at that, we picked up about 70 basis points of expense because of the fact we're now growing earnings at 20% versus 9%. And I don't want to get too deep into the weeds here, but that's -- but despite that 70 basis points, our profitability in that group only went down 20. The other 50 is 'pathway to profit' leverage, which is not only did we improve the profitability of the organization because the mix changed, but the underlying health of the business improved. And where we did get deterioration, it's because of the investments we made, a, and the way our incentive compensation works, b. And I think that's a winning combination.
With that, again, I think our press release broadly gives most people more details than they about the world with Fastenal. With that, I'll stop. And Will, if you have anything you want to add, I'll turn over to Q&A

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question, the spread between vending customers and non-vending customers in terms of the growth rates is -- continues to moderate. How should we look at that? I'm -- the concern obviously is this would be a reflection of the maturation of the initia
componenttext: First question, the spread between vending customers and non-vending customers in terms of the growth rates is -- continues to moderate. How should we look at that? I'm -- the concern obviously is this would be a reflection of the maturation of the initiative, but there's got to be some other factors are components driving the contraction of the spread.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's really a function -- if you look at the growth of the customers who are vending, they've been up -- they've been in the neighborhood of representing about 40% of our sales, so that group of customers. It inches up a little bit every qua
componenttext: Well, I think it's really a function -- if you look at the growth of the customers who are vending, they've been up -- they've been in the neighborhood of representing about 40% of our sales, so that group of customers. It inches up a little bit every quarter, but it's been in the upper 30s. Now it's approaching 40. The growth has been basically 20% all year. I would say that the moderation of spread is really about the fact that the other 60% of our business, the investments made in people at the store and at this district level, the rest of the business has lifted itself up. It isn't so much that the gap has narrowed, it's  the performance of the other 60% has improved, and it's raised our company number. Because we've been basically a 20% growth for the group for the entire year.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015

componenttext: And part of that is a little bit in the fast if you look at a year ago, the Fastenal business, we've seen almost no growth at all. Bringing that growth back basically does not come through vending. It's non-vending business. It changes the mix a little bit business.

componenttext: Helpful. follow-up question, how do you look at this? I guess a million-dollar question. How do you look at gross margins here in 2015, both early on and for the year? I know you voiced a 51% expectation. What are your thoughts are around pricing and fasteners and non-fasteners? And how realistic the 51% expectation should be for the year and for near term?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the 51%, I frankly don't know. What I can tell you is I think what we demonstrated this quarter is we can invest heavily in the business. We can manage expenses 'pathway to profit' mechanics shine through in our profit growth, and we can do that withou
componenttext: On the 51%, I frankly don't know. What I can tell you is I think what we demonstrated this quarter is we can invest heavily in the business. We can manage expenses 'pathway to profit' mechanics shine through in our profit growth, and we can do that without expansion of gross margin. And to me, that's the most . It's a competitive market out there right now. Our mix, as we talked on prior calls, is not -- doesn't -- isn't inherent to raising margin. If you talk about the growth drivers of our business. But the profitability on this growth drivers is great when it comes to the pretext line.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of other positives of the margin, and we do have a couple of . One is we still have a tremendous opportunity on upside for exclusive brands, our private brands. And the other is our transportation cost, with fuel where it is or oil situation, is
componenttext: A couple of other positives of the margin, and we do have a couple of . One is we still have a tremendous opportunity on upside for exclusive brands, our private brands. And the other is our transportation cost, with fuel where it is or oil situation, is going to drop. as you saw in the fourth -- or as you see in the fourth quarter and other quarters or late quarters, the flexibility of our fuel and the cost going up in our fuel and utilization, our utilization will be high in the first quarter of our transportation. And as it looks right now, fuel costs will be down. So to gross margin, that's great. So exclusive brands, tailwind there on the fuel. And also our fastener business is doing a little bit better. So there are gives and takes over the place in margin, and it's always going to be a fight. But I tell you what the team has done a great job of managing our margin through changing business environment.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: So no reason to think why the 28% to 30% -- 20% to 33% incremental margins should not hold true in '15?
componenttext: So no reason to think why the 28% to 30% -- 20% to 33% incremental margins should not hold true in '15?

componenttext: we feel very good about our ability to get strong incremental margins. We in July -- well in April, we talked about getting to 20% in the third quarter -- or excuse me, in the third quarter -- third quarter call, we talked about this quarter of really being in the upper 20s, and we feel pretty good about where we are positioned going into 2015.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think one of the other reasons I feel good about that is we made very heavy investments at the end of '13 in our district managers, a lot of outside sales people outside of the stores. And so we are in a heavy investment mode. We can -- we don't have to
componenttext: I think one of the other reasons I feel good about that is we made very heavy investments at the end of '13 in our district managers, a lot of outside sales people outside of the stores. And so we are in a heavy investment mode. We can -- we don't have to do much of that this year. In fact, in the leadership roles, distro, original, outside salespeople, we're very set for at least the first 6 months of the year. And so we'll be able -- that will come through in the P&L an incremental gross margins or incremental margins.

You see when you look at our vending numbers because a good chunk of that is larger call business, business, and you see that the rest of the group like we talk on that first question, the rest of the group has stepped up and gotten closer to it. So we actually have a little bit more balanced growth and impact on gross margin in the next 12 months, and we probably did in the last 24. Because by adding selling energy into the store, the local business is step up to the plate a little bit more so it's not being told by the vending -- the larger comp business. But are there still a little bit of mixed right there, but we'll touch on about the fuel and our private brands is really powerful.

componenttext: Guess I would the mix is not -- I mean, other distributors have said this . It's not unusual is an industry larger customers are contributing more. headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: SG&A as a percentage of sales is down about 54 basis points this year to just under 30%. And you pointed out that you had pretty tight controls on expenses, especially in the fourth quarter. You also said that you're going to add some more heads in '15 to
componenttext: SG&A as a percentage of sales is down about 54 basis points this year to just under 30%. And you pointed out that you had pretty tight controls on expenses, especially in the fourth quarter. You also said that you're going to add some more heads in '15 to kind of resume what you are doing in '14. I was just curious how do you see those 2, in aggregate, focus on cost control, but also adding heads? How do you see that aggregating into your SG&A as a percent of sales?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: We think about the 'pathway to profit', everything about that including adding heads is about leveraging your SG&A. And so that -- in order to get the 28 to 30, low 30s incremental margin type we talked about, from our perspective, that's all coming from
componenttext: We think about the 'pathway to profit', everything about that including adding heads is about leveraging your SG&A. And so that -- in order to get the 28 to 30, low 30s incremental margin type we talked about, from our perspective, that's all coming from SG&A. The position we're in is that when you look at the labor growth for next year, the SG&A growth for next year, a lot of the incentive pieces, like I talk -- touched on what we give up in the fourth quarter year-over-year because there's actually bonuses paid out again. But that's in our numbers now. That's been growing into our numbers as we've gone through the year stepping up a little bit every quarter. And so it's really puts us in a position to make investments. But the rest of the expense pull release and going that fast. And so we think we're in a great position to manage the SG&A going into 2015.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: So in terms of the store count, you closed 52 stores in the second half, ahead of that initial 45 target. Are closings largely done at this point? And how should we think about net store count additions in 2015?
componenttext: So in terms of the store count, you closed 52 stores in the second half, ahead of that initial 45 target. Are closings largely done at this point? And how should we think about net store count additions in 2015?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Net store count additions, I would expect to be positive in '15, marginally positive. There's -- we're always looking at our business. And even before we announced the 45 in the second quarter, I think we closed around 20 stores in the first half of the y
componenttext: Net store count additions, I would expect to be positive in '15, marginally positive. There's -- we're always looking at our business. And even before we announced the 45 in the second quarter, I think we closed around 20 stores in the first half of the year. And we think that's a healthy thing because in our business, our locations are about -- in my mind, and the disagree with me my approach on this, but my thought about our locations, it's a base for our salespeople that stocks inventory and customers of the ability to stock. And so we can do a great same-day service in a high level to service for our customers. But if we come -- one of our district original leaders looks at the market and say, "I think this market is better served having us operate out of 4 points than 5, or 3 points than 4, when we know we're going to retain an incredibly high percentage of that business," look and say what's the smartest way to grow. But to answer your question, I would expect it to be nominally positive in 2015.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Western Canada, Alaska. We really looked at that, and that's about 10% to 12%. We're going to fill it now. What happens is I think when you look back in time when oil dropped, by the time it drops to the net effect where it hits us, it could be 6 months o
componenttext: Western Canada, Alaska. We really looked at that, and that's about 10% to 12%. We're going to fill it now. What happens is I think when you look back in time when oil dropped, by the time it drops to the net effect where it hits us, it could be 6 months out there or something. There is that lag. So we're keeping an eye on it, and we're definitely going to fill in those regions. The flip side is we don't quite understand what it's going to do to our other customers. Because it actually puts a little winde your sails, so to speak, from the bottom line. So that's kind of how we look at it and how it affects the company today.

componenttext: Well, with growth where we've talked about it in that mid-teens neighborhood, we're in a position to invest in energy at our stores, and really get in the neighborhood of those operating margin -- incremental margins, Dave. Because when I look at our bonus pools, our incentive comp, it really stepped up, when I look at it in the 4 quarters of this year, it really stepped up when we got into second quarter. In the first quarter, it was a pretty healthy number, too, but it really stepped up. And so I think that they are expense is really in our numbers when I look at the totality of '15. And I think it positions us well. And the opposite to that, some of the pieces you normally don't count on in the has touch on it and will touch on it earlier if you have some SG&A that's going the other way the short term. In energy prices for heating a lot of our locations in the Northern country and throughout Canada is a meaningful piece, too. So it gives some tailwind coming into the first part of the year.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, Dave, I'll jump in here. This is Will. But if you -- the biggest component, by far, of our SG&A, as you know, is our labor. And with the plan that Lee and his team have laid out for adding the vast majority of our new selling energy, selling energy s
componenttext: Hey, Dave, I'll jump in here. This is Will. But if you -- the biggest component, by far, of our SG&A, as you know, is our labor. And with the plan that Lee and his team have laid out for adding the vast majority of our new selling energy, selling energy store energy for our sales people can get out hiring college students, we can add 15. Not saying we are going to add 15%, but the math says we can have 15% more hours in our stores, and that would translate into just under 7% labor, not including bonuses. So the base labor to fuel that or just spark that 15% more hours, and those are the scenarios we're looking at. So that gives us a tremendous amount of leverage when you look at that labor is, by far, is biggest expense. We can add the hours with only -- just under half of the expenses as a percentage. That's where a lot of it comes from. And it allows us to be very bullish out there customers and serve our customers at very high level.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the gross margin, I'll just get far too much attention here lately. But the 51%, I'm just -- as I look at historically at the company, it has maintained that level of gross profit profitability. And I know that historically, there's been
componenttext: Okay. And then on the gross margin, I'll just get far too much attention here lately. But the 51%, I'm just -- as I look at historically at the company, it has maintained that level of gross profit profitability. And I know that historically, there's been offsets, whether that was direct sourcing of fasteners are ramp up the exclusive rands or changes to the logistics network, et cetera. So I know that historically, even though National Accounts have moved up in the mix and non-fasteners as a percentage of the mix, you've been able to maintain that level. I'm wondering about is as of those secular changes continue, as they have for the past several decades, are there offsets of that will allow you to remain in that range? Or is it just we reach a point where gross margins could potentially just be lower and have to rely on better cost leverage?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, if you'll recall on the last call, Dave, we -- I probably not so artfully, but I tried to walk through what happens in the 'pathway to profit' as our average store size gets bigger, because I think that's really the underlying cause of a lot of what
componenttext: Well, if you'll recall on the last call, Dave, we -- I probably not so artfully, but I tried to walk through what happens in the 'pathway to profit' as our average store size gets bigger, because I think that's really the underlying cause of a lot of what . Our average store size because we are more and more successful with our large customers. And we doesn't get to those individuals or so purchases store from 80 to 100, or from 100 to 150, or 150 to 200. Over time, you have some 40 and 50,000 dollar a month customers, and -- or maybe $80,000 a month customer. But you have some big business that's coming into those stores. And like I talked about in -- on the last call, if I look at our stores that are -- that do more than 100,000 a month in sales, at the time, that was about just over 1,000 of our 2,700 stores. That group operates at a lower gross margin. I think it was about 70 basis points lower than the company does. And so as we move from 100 to 110 to 130 to 160,000 average store over the next few years, because we're only nominally adding units, so that meets our average store size is going to grow. I would expect our gross margin to compress, and right now, I would expect it to be closer to 50 than that say 51 or 50.5 that we just reported, because of the impact of that. But as I also talked about, giving up 70 basis points, you give up -- pick up about 450 basis points in operating leverage, and that's the secret.

componenttextpreview: That's growing out over 1, 2, 3 years.
componenttext: That's growing out over 1, 2, 3 years.

componenttext: Absolutely. I mean, that's looking out into the future ...

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Eli Lustgarten with Longbow Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Eli Lustgarten with Longbow Securities.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: The overemphasis of gross margin has finally been recognized. I have two questions. One, can we talk about sort of current business conditions as we look out into '15? Particularly, first the quarter has a very easy comp as we did the December from the we
componenttext: The overemphasis of gross margin has finally been recognized. I have two questions. One, can we talk about sort of current business conditions as we look out into '15? Particularly, first the quarter has a very easy comp as we did the December from the weather impact a year ago, so it doesn't repeat. Last year, if you -- nobody January, February so quickly. Can you give us some idea of some benefits from their? And the second part of that thing, can you talk about the heavy manufacturing impact? 20% of your business. But can you talk about the impact of ag and the Canadian economy, which is now starting to show signs of stress on the Fastenal? Particularly if the ag market, which we know is crashing at the moment, and whether Canada is becoming a bit of a problem or not?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Bunch of -- quite a few items there, but I'll try to browse through a few. And Lee or Will, if you want to chime in, feel free. First off, on the end market piece, the manufacturing. That business really improved for us, and I think that's really shi
componenttext: Yes. Bunch of -- quite a few items there, but I'll try to browse through a few. And Lee or Will, if you want to chime in, feel free. First off, on the end market piece, the manufacturing. That business really improved for us, and I think that's really shines through in the fact that we exit the year with our fastener business growing double digit. We started the year with our fastener business growing low singles, 1, 1.5% in the first quarter, 1.9% fourth quarter of last year. That says a lot to the health of our OEM manufacturing customer out there. So I think that has a very good trends going into the new year. When I think of our Canadian business -- and I know enough some -- about a lot of the details, I get myself in the trouble in the conversation. To me, the biggest issue we have with our Canadian business right now isn't how well it's growing. It's the value of the currency. That business grew for us in the mid-single -- in the mid-double digit, excuse me, here when im x looking at the last few months. But what shines through on our company level, when you look at it in USD, it cuts that down by almost 2/3 because of deflation in the currency. But the underlying business up there is -- for us, is healthy. One thing to keep in mind when you look at our business in Canada, it is weighted towards the eastern part of the country. We went in Ontario first, and because we were expanding from basically the Great Lakes states in the U.S. when we first entered Canada in mid-'90s. So have a big chunk of business that's in Ontario province and then, out towards the . It was later that we more expanded into Western Canada from the standpoint of where our arts. And that business, the eastern part of the country stronger than the western part up as of the Western part is Lane to what industries.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you can talk about the weather impact and ag and the   out there.
componenttext: If you can talk about the weather impact and ag and the   out there.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the weather coming into last year, we had a tough start to the year. Weather really beat us up. And weather, while it's been cold in the Upper Midwest, hasn't been pounded by the weather you saw. And time will tell how that plays out the rest of Jan
componenttext: Well, the weather coming into last year, we had a tough start to the year. Weather really beat us up. And weather, while it's been cold in the Upper Midwest, hasn't been pounded by the weather you saw. And time will tell how that plays out the rest of January and into February, but I don't see weather as a threat right now.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: We did have a good March last year, so that balances it out too weather-wise. We came back very strong. so it wasn't entire quarter that was affected. mainly January.
componenttext: We did have a good March last year, so that balances it out too weather-wise. We came back very strong. so it wasn't entire quarter that was affected. mainly January.

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can I -- one other question. You had an initiative in metalworking that was started several years ago, which really hasn't done very much. I mean, the relationship with Kennametal really seems to be plodding along. Is that still the focus of the company o
componenttext: Can I -- one other question. You had an initiative in metalworking that was started several years ago, which really hasn't done very much. I mean, the relationship with Kennametal really seems to be plodding along. Is that still the focus of the company or a future growth, whatever? Or is it sort of put on the back burner?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll jump in on that. Metalworking continues to do well. Our relationship with Kennametal is good. People I think have too high an expectation going in thinking we're going to be as big as MSC overnight, and that doesn't happen. metalworking business has
componenttext: I'll jump in on that. Metalworking continues to do well. Our relationship with Kennametal is good. People I think have too high an expectation going in thinking we're going to be as big as MSC overnight, and that doesn't happen. metalworking business has grown, not double digit, but also double digit above the fastener growth over the last -- over -- in 2014. It even did better than 2013, and we've grown a very nice business. We're doing well with it. We think the upside is good. It's hard to grow our business that now, represents about 10 -- just under 10% of our total revenue. So it's a meaningful sized business, and it's hard to grow at more than 20-plus percent year-over-year with a business that big. So we're very committed. We think we're going to continue to do well in it for a long time. And part of it is what we learned is, although Kennametal is a very good supplier, they don't have full spectrum of what the customers need, and neither does any of the other suppliers. So we have developed relationships with a wide range of suppliers and most we were enjoying very good growth through Fastenal. So we're still very committed and believe it's a great opportunity for the future of Fastenal. The making that makes sense. Is our fastener and MRO customers, most of those are using metalworking products. We already have developed relationships. Now we have to develop the product relationship in the specific area.

componenttext: Just want to clarify the 10% to 12% is that was tied to oil and gas. Is that direct energy customers? Or were you saying that 10% to 12% of our stores are in energy levered states?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015

componenttext: No, 10% to 12% of our sales are in those geographic areas. And I would -- shooting from the hip, I would say probably half of that would be closer to the energy piece. But that's somewhat talking to our regional leaders in those geographic areas. But it's really looking at the Gulf Coast, the Texas market, Western Pennsylvania, Western North Dakota, up in Oklahoma and Western Canada. Kind of looking at those and gauging it.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: And it's pretty close to 12%, and more information that grew in the third quarter, grew at about 24% versus the company. We are -- we have enjoyed very nice growth. So that's the -- we have 12% of our business. It will probably slow down. I mean, that --
componenttext: And it's pretty close to 12%, and more information that grew in the third quarter, grew at about 24% versus the company. We are -- we have enjoyed very nice growth. So that's the -- we have 12% of our business. It will probably slow down. I mean, that -- yes, probably. But the other part of our business, the 90% or 88% remaining, we're hoping we're going to get a little tailwind through lower energy costs, and maybe it balances. If doesn't balance, we also have about a $12 million a quarter energy -- or $10 million energy bill that we think is going to go down by $3 million or $4 million. So we could give up a little revenue and balance with the expense. We're hoping we don't give up any revenue, and we get to capitalize on expense. So we look at that and we're trying to figure it out. But there's no crystal ball for this right now. It's all about how the rest of the economy is affected because of lower fuel prices.

componenttext: Yes, okay. I just want to be clear. That would have been bigger than I would have thought, but 5% makes sense, which would be direct. Okay. Second question, given the decline in steel prices, should we be worried about deflation in fasteners? And can you just remind us how your fastener contracts work with regard to price?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: The large contracts, which probably make up 20% to 25% of our fastener business, are tied to SEIU Index, which is a steel index. And where the triggers on that are typically -- they're not all the same, but most, majority of them, have a 5% trigger. So as
componenttext: The large contracts, which probably make up 20% to 25% of our fastener business, are tied to SEIU Index, which is a steel index. And where the triggers on that are typically -- they're not all the same, but most, majority of them, have a 5% trigger. So as steel goes down more than 5% ...

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Or up.
componenttext: Or up.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Or up, more than 5% over a 6-month period, it's always on the calendar. January and July are the trigger points. We will either raise our prices or lower our price accordingly. And then, based on that, we're figuring out what percent. So if steel goes up
componenttext: Or up, more than 5% over a 6-month period, it's always on the calendar. January and July are the trigger points. We will either raise our prices or lower our price accordingly. And then, based on that, we're figuring out what percent. So if steel goes up 5% or down, it doesn't mean we lower our price because we factor in the labor. So there's a formula there. So the other 75% of our business is not on these contracts. When steel goes down, we have some upside for margin if we can hold on to that pricing. And that's really where we think the balance is. There's always margin pressure exposure if there's a lot of deflation in the business. So far, we have not seen a lot, but that time will tell. We've been very close with our guys in Asia that are running our business for us. trading business and trying to understand what the manufacturers are seeing -- seeing.

componenttext: And what would the lag be?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could slip one more in, kind of a big picture question. There's a view by some that the MRO industry is more competitive, more consolidated today, and therefore, the growth going forward would be lower, potentially less profitable. So what
componenttext: Okay. And if I could slip one more in, kind of a big picture question. There's a view by some that the MRO industry is more competitive, more consolidated today, and therefore, the growth going forward would be lower, potentially less profitable. So what is your view? And has anything changed in your view over the past 10 years?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, things have changed. But if you look at the big players or whoever you throw into that group, we've all grown nicely, but -- so maybe we've gone from 25% market share to 28% or 30%. So it has consolidated, but pretty slow rate when you look at -- co
componenttext: Well, things have changed. But if you look at the big players or whoever you throw into that group, we've all grown nicely, but -- so maybe we've gone from 25% market share to 28% or 30%. So it has consolidated, but pretty slow rate when you look at -- combined, if you look at us, and Grainger combined. There's others, I know. But our growth is probably 10% if add us all up. It takes a long time to consolidate the industry. It's always been competitive and I think remain competitive. But there's a tremendous amount of opportunity out there, and we think is the opportunity as good as it's ever been. That's why we're so focused, as Lee talked about earlier, about staying close to our customers, using our same model to grow our business and take market share.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from line of Adam Uhlman with Cleveland Research.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can we go to the cash flow outlook for next year? Pretty good job this year in getting cash conversion, I guess. How should we be thinking about CapEx? What do you think inventory side? That would be helpful.
componenttext: Can we go to the cash flow outlook for next year? Pretty good job this year in getting cash conversion, I guess. How should we be thinking about CapEx? What do you think inventory side? That would be helpful.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our CapEx will drop as we go into the new year. The number I would expect us to be citing in our annual report would be a number of around 1 50 plus or minus $5 million. And I think we're positioned well. I think we're in a good position to manage the wor
componenttext: Our CapEx will drop as we go into the new year. The number I would expect us to be citing in our annual report would be a number of around 1 50 plus or minus $5 million. And I think we're positioned well. I think we're in a good position to manage the working capital needs. The biggest component of need there would be more on the AR side than the inventory because I expect our business to keep growing nicely. And I think it puts us in a great position to generate very, very strong cash flow. And our operating cash flow this year was  even high by our norm because we basically had operating cash up essentially in line with earnings. Part of that was the fact that our friends in Washington, D.C. saw fit to continue the bonus depreciation and a few other things there. So we didn't get that tax bill coming and that defers deferrals that off. But really a strong operating cash flow year, and I think we have a great position for next year, because a lot of those investments in distribution are in the rearview mirror rather than in the windshield.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got you. And then, clarification on the headcount. It's been asked so many times, but it's still not clear to me. We had 2% year-over-year growth in December on FTEs. And I'm just wondering how you think about that for the first half of this next ye
componenttext: Okay, got you. And then, clarification on the headcount. It's been asked so many times, but it's still not clear to me. We had 2% year-over-year growth in December on FTEs. And I'm just wondering how you think about that for the first half of this next year. Are we going to bounce back to the 10% of 15% that was mentioned earlier? Or are we going to remain in the single digits? And then, ramp back up?

componenttext: No, the total headcount growth on an FTE basis. Year-over-year in December, can we stay there some time?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. You really have to discount a lot of what the year-over-year numbers are in November and December. Because in November and December a year ago, as I touched on earlier, we are in this massive ramp-up stage and the hours just dial-up because we want t
componenttext: Yes. You really have to discount a lot of what the year-over-year numbers are in November and December. Because in November and December a year ago, as I touched on earlier, we are in this massive ramp-up stage and the hours just dial-up because we want to get our salespeople out of the store selling. And this year as we managed through it, we were able to dial down the part-time hours in November and in December. And that's really what -- of that drives in the FTE. And one of the reasons I put that bullet in on Page 1 was really talking about, hey, on the headline, it looks like we dropped our hours, our numbers at the store. Our FTE did go down because of the hours, but we actually added people. And so coming into January and February, that will dial back up because we have the need.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: And when we look at trying to normalize taking out people going home for the holidays and all that, we're in the high single digits. We think we have 8% to 9% more selling energy if everybody was at work all week long. And that's a little lower than we wa
componenttext: And when we look at trying to normalize taking out people going home for the holidays and all that, we're in the high single digits. We think we have 8% to 9% more selling energy if everybody was at work all week long. And that's a little lower than we want, but it's in the neighborhood. Does that makes sense, Adam?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and so that's the kind of get back to that normalized 8% to 9%, then, maybe grow from there as you have need?
componenttext: Yes, and so that's the kind of get back to that normalized 8% to 9%, then, maybe grow from there as you have need?

componenttext: Yes we want to push it up from there, yes.
