headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fastenal Company First Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conferen
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fastenal Company First Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Jane [ph]. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome to the Fastenal Company 2015 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This call will be hosted by Lee Hein, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Dan Florness, our Chief Financial Officer. The call will last for up to 45 minutes
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome to the Fastenal Company 2015 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This call will be hosted by Lee Hein, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Dan Florness, our Chief Financial Officer. The call will last for up to 45 minutes. The call will start with a general overview of our quarterly results and operations by Lee and Dan, with the remainder of the time being open for questions and answers. Today's conference call is a proprietary Fastenal presentation and is being recorded by Fastenal. No recording, reproduction, transmission or distribution of today's call is permitted without Fastenal's consent. This call is being audio simulcast on the Internet via the Fastenal Investor Relations home page, investor.fastenal.com. A replay of the webcast will be available on the website until June 1, 2015, at midnight Central Time. 
As a reminder, today's conference call includes statements regarding the company's anticipated financial and operating results as well as other forward-looking statements based on current expectations as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements may often be identified with words such as we expect, we anticipate, upcoming or similar indications of future expectations. It is important to note that the company's actual results may differ materially from those anticipated. Information on factors that could cause results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements are contained in the company's periodic filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and we encourage you to review those carefully. Investors are cautioned not to place undue reliance on such forward-looking statements, as there is no assurance that the matter contained in such statements will occur. Forward-looking statements are made as of today's date only, and we undertake no duty to update the information provided on this call. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Lee Hein.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jane. Good morning, and welcome to our Q1 2015 call. [indiscernible] when you look at it, it's really 2 stories, one things we can control and things we cannot control. Obviously, the things outside of our control, the currency, weather, oil and g
componenttext:
Thanks, Jane. Good morning, and welcome to our Q1 2015 call. [indiscernible] when you look at it, it's really 2 stories, one things we can control and things we cannot control. Obviously, the things outside of our control, the currency, weather, oil and gas and the port situation in California. But the things we can control, I think when I look at the Fastenal team, I think it was a solid quarter. With that being said, I will always say this when we see single-digit revenue growth, we're not satisfied nor are we happy. But with 8.8% growth, we did some things, and I think have talked to the Fastenal team when you look at some different areas. 
When I look at the fact that we stabilized our gross margins and I know there's been questions there, but I look at the fact that we were able to do some things there and a lot of that is truly execution when you really look at what our people are doing at the point of transaction. The second thing, we challenged our Fastenal team to really live within our means and what I mean by that, that's an old-school BK philosophy that if we don't need it, don't buy it. And you saw that play out in the first quarter when you look at meal, travel and entertainment. We made a conscious decision to spend our money on labor in the stores. We said no to things that may sound nice and may actually help us long-term in some regards but today, we made a decision to invest in our stores, to fuel our growth, to drive profits, and that's what you saw play out on the expense side, even when you take out the tailwind on the fuel. 
The other thing, some other highlights, we grew earnings 14%. That's a nice leverage when you consider we're at 8.8% on the daily average growth. More importantly, and more impressive, I think is the team was able to put up 32.2% incremental margin growth. Again, a number that I think most companies would just -- would be thrilled with. 
When you look at the added energy in the store, I want to -- this is where we really got to get down to what's truly happening boots on the ground. From the end of Q3 2014 up until the end of Q1 2015, we've added 1,000 people into our stores. Now most of those heads came in the last half of Q1. January, folks, I got to tell you, January, coupled with the weather, the fact that the kids aren't back-to-school, it's a rough month for recruiting. But in the second half of February, in the month of March, that's when we started to see the team really start to bring people into the stores. And we'll continue that to looking at a few of our stores. When I look -- I talk about our large stores, our stores with a high number of customer, we would just say a lot of traffic. We're looking at adding products into some of those stores to also build invoice, build the customer satisfaction, all the things that we try to do everyday. 
The other thing and lastly, I think, a shout-out ready to Nick's team on the inventory side coming in at 8 67 [ph] with inventory at 8 69 [ph] a year ago, really is, again, a testament to the Fastenal team and what we can do when we put our minds to it. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Dan.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lee, and good morning, everybody and for those of you that were wondering, he's referring to Nick Lundquist and the team on the supply chain and really a nice job of managing the inventory. Those of you that were wondering I used to refer Nick and
componenttext:
Thanks, Lee, and good morning, everybody and for those of you that were wondering, he's referring to Nick Lundquist and the team on the supply chain and really a nice job of managing the inventory. Those of you that were wondering I used to refer Nick and the team on the supply chain and really nice job of managing the inventory in a tough environment. I'm going -- typical to prior quarters, I'm going to reiterate a few of the points made, and then touch on a few additional. I have the opportunity to talk a lot of folks in the Wall Street community over the course of the months. And one confusion there's a been and what we talked about in the January call, just want to reiterate here, and that is, Lee touched on it and we really are focused on adding energy into the store to free up the time of our sales people to get out and sell more. And as Lee mentioned in the last 12 months, we've added more than 1,000 people, 1,067 to be exact and we intend to keep adding people to the store level. And internally, the way we've described to our folks is, we've just under 300 district managers in the organization. And we would like to be in a position for each of those district managers to, on a net basis, add an employee into their business each month. And most of that hiring is going to be part-time. We continue to want to beef up our ranks on the part-time. It's really a means for us to recruit long-term because we go into 2- and 4-year, 2-year at technical colleges, 4-year state colleges, we recruit people with a year or 2 years off to school with the hopes that when they graduate, they come work for us full time and we can really hit the ground running and we have a daughter to put a lot of training into them during their entire cycle with Fastenal. 
So if we added 300 people a month and say did it for hopefully 9 months, 10 months in the year, maybe 9 months but you'd be adding about 15% to your FTE base in the business. So you add 3,000 people, they work about a little less than 20 hours a week. So you start with a group of 10,000 FTE, you had 1,500 on that 15%. I don't know if when the dust settles at the end of the year if we'll hit that 15% number or if we'll be closer to 12% or 13%. The economy dictate a little bit how hard we push on that. But that's our intention to invest heavily into time in the store and free up our salespeople who are quite frankly the best and industry, free up their time to get out and sell. 
And as Lee touched on, quite a few of those came in the last really 2 months. In the first quarter here we added about 614 people into our store locations. 
A little bit in the release, starting on Page 5, talk about the environment. Tough environment out there. Our sales growth softened as we got deeper into the quarter. Weather hit us hard in the January, February time frame, oil and gas and some of our customers that are involved with export markets, the currencies are -- U.S. -- strong U.S. dollars not helping export. So our business did weakened as we went through the quarter. 
You really see it showing up in the industrial, the production side of our business and as we talk about in the release, the best way to think about that is on the fastener side. Our fasteners grew about 6% for the quarter, they were growing 10% and 11% in the third and fourth quarter of last year. So that business really slowed down. We don't -- we didn't loose any customers but those customers are producing fewer widgets.
are producing fewer widgets and therefore, they need fewer fasteners. The non-fastener business still maintained double-digit growth. It did weakened. It will move directionally with the other business. But that is a much -- that's a more resilient piece of business for us and part of it really stems the fact that it's heavily influenced by our vending initiative over the last 5 years.
The page -- starting on Page 10, we talk about the earnings. And probably, the things that jump up for me when I look at it personally is I frankly think it's a pretty impressive report. And I'm the first one to let our folks know when we've had a weak quarter. I'm also the first one to let them know we've had a strong quarter. And I think from an execution standpoint, we put on a nice report because we actually hit it well. I mean, we added, in last 12 months, over 1,000 people into our stores, we've managed our labor expenses well. We managed our nonlabor expenses even better. We were helped obviously by the fuel and gas prices in our business but that is a known item for everybody. But even outside of that, we did a wonderful job managing our business. 
Finally, cash flow. Cash flow was very strong, partly as Lee touched on, we did a nice job with our inventory but a strong performance looking at all aspects of the cash flow statement. 
Some things that might be worth pointing out late yesterday, we announced our second quarter dividend of $0.28 a share. That is consistent with our dividend in the first quarter. Late March, we announced that our board had increased our repurchase authorization for buying back stock to 4 million shares. Just to give you a brief history on that, in January, they established a 2 million share authorization. From mid-February until the latter part of March, we spent and bought back 2 million shares. We spent roughly $82 million. We bought back stock at just under $41 a share. This depleted that authority. Therefore, we asked our board, and they agreed, to establish a $4 million authorization to use going forward. We have been in the process of increasing our credit facility, so we're in a position to exercise that if the market sees fit and we'll see how that plays out. 
I think the report is pretty straightforward this quarter. There's not a lot of noise to it. Obviously, the top line weakening is probably the noteworthy thing again, everybody had seen the January, February numbers, so there's no surprises there. 
And I have one item I'll throw out as a reminder, and then we'll switch over to question-and-answer and that reminder is, just a reminder folks, our annual meeting is next Tuesday at 10 a.m. 
With that, we'll turn it over to Q&A.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Robert Barry from Susquehanna.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Robert Barry from Susquehanna.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I did -- I wanted to start by asking about gross margin because you mentioned that you had stabilized it in the quarter and that's a positive, but it sounds like the language in the release sharpened a little bit this quarter and now seems to call for ong
componenttext: I did -- I wanted to start by asking about gross margin because you mentioned that you had stabilized it in the quarter and that's a positive, but it sounds like the language in the release sharpened a little bit this quarter and now seems to call for ongoing decline as average store size grows and since you're not adding stores, it sounds like essentially saying gross margin decline as the business grows. So can you clarify what the expectation is for the gross margin going forward?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take that one, and I don't recall if it was the January call or the October call but in that previous call, one of the things that I don't know that people always appreciate, we've talked about our pathway to profit table for years and in that p
componenttext: Yes, I'll take that one, and I don't recall if it was the January call or the October call but in that previous call, one of the things that I don't know that people always appreciate, we've talked about our pathway to profit table for years and in that pathway to profit, as our stores materially become more profitable because we've dramatically leverage the fixed cost structure of our business. The flip side of that coin is, if we're visiting a $50,000, you don't have very many $20,000 and $30,000 month customer in that store. I'd be surprised if you have even have one. You visit $150,000 and you could have several, you could have 3 customers doing $20,000 and $30,000 a month. And those customers, first off, they have more ability to negotiate pricing but more importantly than that, we have the ability to go after that business from a different way because that market is a little difference. And so you've offer business because you have more predictability of what you need is and you can be a little sharper with your pencil because you know that those revenue dollars are more importantly than those gross profit dollars. While there's some added expense to serving them, you're still in the same building. You're still the same semi-delivering product. And so when we move from $100,000, if you look at all of our stores over $100,000, our average store in that group is about $165,000 a month. Our gross margin in that group and I'm just reiterating what we talked about earlier, our gross margin of that group is about 90 to 100 basis points lower than the rest of our stores. However, our operating expenses dropped off around 450 basis points. So that $165,000 has profit relative to sales dollars, it's 350 basis points higher, but there's some trade-up. You've given up a little bit of gross margin, you're picking up in operating leverage. We like that trade-offs and so as we move -- once we popped above $100,000 a month in sales, as we move further away from $100,000 a month, I would expect our gross margin to decline. And I'll take that trade-up of $1 here for $4.50 over there.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it sounds like the outlook for gross margin is essentially a secular decline, but you expect to more than make up for it at the operating margin level through SG&A leverage?
componenttext: Yes. So it sounds like the outlook for gross margin is essentially a secular decline, but you expect to more than make up for it at the operating margin level through SG&A leverage?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. 3 to 1, 3.5 to 1.
componenttext: Yes. 3 to 1, 3.5 to 1.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I noticed you took the table out of the release this quarter that shows how the margins are progressing in the various store buckets, I don't know if that will be in the queue. But maybe you can just share some thoughts on what has been happening with
componenttext: And I noticed you took the table out of the release this quarter that shows how the margins are progressing in the various store buckets, I don't know if that will be in the queue. But maybe you can just share some thoughts on what has been happening with the margin in the largest bucket because it looked at it has been declining?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, the operating margin improved and you see that shine through. If you look at our stores that deliver $100,000 a month, that's half our revenue. And so our overall profits are up 100 a basis points from last year. That group was a big piece of t
componenttext: Yes. Well, the operating margin improved and you see that shine through. If you look at our stores that deliver $100,000 a month, that's half our revenue. And so our overall profits are up 100 a basis points from last year. That group was a big piece of that equation. I removed it for a couple of reasons, I think one thing when we started the pathway to profit back in 2007, we dramatically expanded some of the information we disclosed really because it was a big change for Fastenal. 5 years ago, when we introduced the industrial vending, we expanded a bunch of our disclosures because again, that was a big change for Fastenal and one thing we like to be in a position to do always with our shareholders is be able to think out loud, openly and honestly, honestly we feel about what we're doing. I kind of got -- I started the signal last year that I was going to pull back some of the disclosures not because we wanted to disclose less, but we want to make sure that all the stuff that we disclosed doesn't create noise and the takeaway from the message. And it's really -- because you want to focus on here the major things, and hear the minor things. And so what we're trying to pare it back a little bit so we have little bit more concise report. And I have some firm believer after 7, 8 years of showing pathway to profit for the people that believe it, you don't need to see it every quarter. For the people don't believe it, after 8 years, I don't if I'll convince anybody.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Flavio Campos from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Flavio Campos from Credit Suisse.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just focusing on gross margin, just very quickly on Q1 it looks like to fuel helped you about 10 bps a little bit of a reduction to that $8.8 million this quarter. And you guys talked a little bit about seasonality as well, could you just help us bridge t
componenttext: Just focusing on gross margin, just very quickly on Q1 it looks like to fuel helped you about 10 bps a little bit of a reduction to that $8.8 million this quarter. And you guys talked a little bit about seasonality as well, could you just help us bridge that? And if you can also talk a little bit about the fact that on the fastener business, you've had a lot of cost deflation on the supplier side and now, we are seeing a little bit of that price pressure on your customer side as you called out on the release. And if that mismatching timing has also helped gross margin right now? Or if you're actually passing through a lot of the savings?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, no. The gross margin really hasn't helped by any timing. Where we do have contracts that are tied to a CRU or some type of index, it usually mirrors the turn of our inventory. So really when I look at the gross margin and I try to touch on that in th
componenttext: Yes, no. The gross margin really hasn't helped by any timing. Where we do have contracts that are tied to a CRU or some type of index, it usually mirrors the turn of our inventory. So really when I look at the gross margin and I try to touch on that in the release, the improvement in gross margin, there's always a seasonal lift that occurs. And the real impact is, we have a fixed cost with our trucking network. That truck has gone -- our [indiscernible] from Minnesota. Another truck [indiscernible] every morning. Whether that truck is getting 10 packages or 20 packages, cost of truck is the same. And so in -- from October to November and December, our volumes will drop off meaningfully because of the seasonality of the business. And so that fixed cost of that truck weighs a little heavily -- more heavily on the sales. When our sales snapped up in the first quarter, that truck still costs us the same, I'm ignoring fuel here for a second, that truck costus us the same, but we're delivering 10% more boxes. And so that lift is always there and that [indiscernible] always there in the fourth quarter. I think what is more important about our gross margin is, we did more than that. We got the lift that's there. It was added a little bit as you've mentioned because our fuel cost came in less than, say, a year ago. Less than even fourth quarter, although that delta is smaller. But more importantly, we did a better job pricing our product and sourcing our product. A lot of our sourcing is done at the store level, which is fairly unique for industrial distributors in general because we're very entrepreneurial in our nature. And it's really looking at everybody square in the eye and challenging everybody, you know what we need to stop this and stabilize and we did a little bit better than that.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Perfect, perfect. That's very helpful color. If can I just have a quick follow-up on the non-res side of the business. That slowed down a lot in March and that seems to be a little less levered to the headwinds of oil and gas and exports, I'm not sure if
componenttext: Perfect, perfect. That's very helpful color. If can I just have a quick follow-up on the non-res side of the business. That slowed down a lot in March and that seems to be a little less levered to the headwinds of oil and gas and exports, I'm not sure if that's accurate, but if you could just comment on a little bit on the health of that end market?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that business did slowdown for us. One item just to keep in mind, a chunk of our non-res construction is directly tied to energy. It's infrastructure. Because of where we operate and the infrastructure that's being built to support both the productio
componenttext: Yes, that business did slowdown for us. One item just to keep in mind, a chunk of our non-res construction is directly tied to energy. It's infrastructure. Because of where we operate and the infrastructure that's being built to support both the production as well as downstream, refining and transmission in between, we're involved in those 3 stages of oil and gas. So oil and gas does have an impact on our non-res but that business was a little weaker, part of what was weathered-centered. But it did soften a little bit. I think there's a lot of tentativeness in the marketplace right now.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ryan Merkel from William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ryan Merkel from William Blair.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first question, when I look at your March growth rate and I look at the index, it looks like demand is slowing sort of beyond oil and gas and beyond exports. Are you seeing this as well? And what do you think is driving this?
componenttext: So first question, when I look at your March growth rate and I look at the index, it looks like demand is slowing sort of beyond oil and gas and beyond exports. Are you seeing this as well? And what do you think is driving this?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think yes, we are. But I think what you really have is those 2 you mentioned, exports and oil and gas. They cast one heck of a shadow. It's not just the folks that are directly involved in that business. If you're in the same geographic area and the man
componenttext: I think yes, we are. But I think what you really have is those 2 you mentioned, exports and oil and gas. They cast one heck of a shadow. It's not just the folks that are directly involved in that business. If you're in the same geographic area and the manufacturing taste, the manufacturing heart bit of that area is weaker, everything else kind of takes a step-down. If you're working at an industrial business and your -- you're kind of worried about what's going on in your business, people aren't as quick to do other things to buy a car, to buy a -- to make a renovation to their room. People because I don't need to replace this television set today, stuff like that. You just become a little bit more conservative because everybody's a little nervous.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ryan, I'd jump in, the other thing on the oil and gas, last call, we talked about it being 10% to 12% from a geography standpoint but even when you start to consider the steel mill that's making the frac pipe, we didn't even -- that's not even part of our
componenttext: Ryan, I'd jump in, the other thing on the oil and gas, last call, we talked about it being 10% to 12% from a geography standpoint but even when you start to consider the steel mill that's making the frac pipe, we didn't even -- that's not even part of our discussion this quarter, but there is a ripple effect that I think, as Dan said, that is greater than I think most people really understand.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And asked a different way, do you have the growth rate in the quarter for the energy states and the nonenergy states, was there a big difference there?
componenttext: Okay. And asked a different way, do you have the growth rate in the quarter for the energy states and the nonenergy states, was there a big difference there?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't have that right in front of me, Ryan. But if I was looking at the energy in general, in the case of March, was probably a 3% impact.
componenttext: I don't have that right in front of me, Ryan. But if I was looking at the energy in general, in the case of March, was probably a 3% impact.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then incremental margins were very strong as you pointed out, but I'm just wondering if growth kind of stay at 6%, 7% range, and then you're going to ramp the FTEs a bit it sounds like, what's the reasonable incremental margin range in your mind
componenttext: Okay. And then incremental margins were very strong as you pointed out, but I'm just wondering if growth kind of stay at 6%, 7% range, and then you're going to ramp the FTEs a bit it sounds like, what's the reasonable incremental margin range in your mind if we look at Q2, 3Q, 4Q?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, one thing to keep in mind is once -- second quarter and third quarter last year, our gross margin was at 50.8%. Fourth quarter, it took a little dip down and now we're back at 50.8%. So we could be in a position to invest well and if the nice of gro
componenttext: Well, one thing to keep in mind is once -- second quarter and third quarter last year, our gross margin was at 50.8%. Fourth quarter, it took a little dip down and now we're back at 50.8%. So we could be in a position to invest well and if the nice of gross margin is silent, it's really about our operating expenses. And I see no reason why, yes, I don't know if we'll stay North of 30, but I feel very good about staying North of 25.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from with Luke [ph] with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from with Luke [ph] with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just building off on your last there on the gross margin line, Dan. Just kind of way out in terms of the outlook for the rest of the year, things that you can't control and some of the things, say, working on the pricing side versus maybe some of the head
componenttext: Just building off on your last there on the gross margin line, Dan. Just kind of way out in terms of the outlook for the rest of the year, things that you can't control and some of the things, say, working on the pricing side versus maybe some of the headwinds we might face this year, especially in the fastener product line just how this dynamics interact that may be better understanding as we're seeing the drop in steel prices right now and the piece of your business that you're probably churning less than 2x per year just how you'd expect similar steel prices to work its way into the P&L as we go forward here.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the lower steel prices, anytime you have deflation, it creates a challenging environment and we've in a situation having deflation now for a few years. And so it makes challenging as we go through the year. At the end of the day though, I really loo
componenttext: Well, the lower steel prices, anytime you have deflation, it creates a challenging environment and we've in a situation having deflation now for a few years. And so it makes challenging as we go through the year. At the end of the day though, I really look at that in at a longer-term perspective than just that because I try to understand what are the long-term drivers of our gross margin because that really the things that you focus on. And the long-term drivers of our gross margin really gets down to business and product mix. So customer mix coming with customers at sizes. One thing that we've done a nice job in recent years and by recent years I'm saying the last 15, but we've done a nice job of leveraging this infrastructure that is Fastenal, the store base of Fastenal and growing our large business quite aggressively. That continues to outgrow the rest of the business. Not because we're losing opportunities in the smaller customer base, it's because we're underrepresented in the large customer base. And so we continue to grow a little bit faster there. To me, long-term, the growth in that large customer base as well as the residual impact to our product mix, that ultimately drives our gross margin. And as we see, as our revenue base grows and our gross margin does decline a bit, we do a very nice job of our business model leveraging that cost and doing a nice job with the pretax, which really at the end of the day is of all the numbers in the P&L, really the only one that matters the one at the bottom of the page. Every else above that is just discussion points. But it still healthy to appreciate the points and understand how that differs from business. But ultimately, it gets down to what our customer mix and what's our product mix within these customers.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow, Lee, had mentioned that the port situation did impact you during the quarter. Just curious at a high-level what impact it may have had on your supply chain on product pricing you need source any product domestically typically import, et cet
componenttext: Just a follow, Lee, had mentioned that the port situation did impact you during the quarter. Just curious at a high-level what impact it may have had on your supply chain on product pricing you need source any product domestically typically import, et cetera?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: We kind of tried to get a message to our folks that we thought this thing would get rectified and to really try to take care of our customers but really we took, I think, a fairly tough stance. We're not going to go out and find something or secure parts
componenttext: We kind of tried to get a message to our folks that we thought this thing would get rectified and to really try to take care of our customers but really we took, I think, a fairly tough stance. We're not going to go out and find something or secure parts domestically and eat the difference. So we did a nice job there to put a number and I can't do that. But it caused, I think, for maybe a few months of a month a little bit of problems here and there. But nothing to the degree that it really moved the needle for us on the margin side.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: One thing that helps us in situations like this is the fact that we have inventory terms of roughly 2x a year. So we have more resiliency than our peers really do when it comes to this matter because with the 2,600, 2,700 store locations and 14 distributi
componenttext: One thing that helps us in situations like this is the fact that we have inventory terms of roughly 2x a year. So we have more resiliency than our peers really do when it comes to this matter because with the 2,600, 2,700 store locations and 14 distribution centers, we have a lot of inventory store growth in the country.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Charles Redding with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Charles Redding with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you can drill a little more on Canada. I realize your exposure certainly more heavily weighted towards the Eastern market. Have you seen weakness there?  [indiscernible] direct oil and gas exposure? Are you seeing that bleed over into some of
componenttext: I wonder if you can drill a little more on Canada. I realize your exposure certainly more heavily weighted towards the Eastern market. Have you seen weakness there?  [indiscernible] direct oil and gas exposure? Are you seeing that bleed over into some of the more ancillary markets?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: For Western Canada, obviously, our business there has been impacted pretty dramatically. And yes, it bleeds over into everything in that geographic area. As you noted in your question, the -- when we originally entered Canada, we entered from essentially
componenttext: For Western Canada, obviously, our business there has been impacted pretty dramatically. And yes, it bleeds over into everything in that geographic area. As you noted in your question, the -- when we originally entered Canada, we entered from essentially southern Ontario and grew through Ontario, and then from there, expanded East and West. So the core of our business is really in the province of Ontario. That business there had held up reasonably well if I'm looking at Canadian dollar, Canadian dollar. Obviously, the Canadian currency is very much tied to the fact that their economy is tied to extractive industries and the weakness in oil and gas, weakness in energy in general has not helped their currency. So we're in a local-currency basis, we're growing reasonably well. But when you look convert to USD, and that's what we report in, the picture isn't quite so good but the underlying business is solid.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on heavy manufacturing and ag, I know your exposure there is relatively [indiscernible] as well but if you could just color -- provide a little more color on heavy maturing right now kind of trends where you're seeing that and how you're se
componenttext: Okay. And then on heavy manufacturing and ag, I know your exposure there is relatively [indiscernible] as well but if you could just color -- provide a little more color on heavy maturing right now kind of trends where you're seeing that and how you're seeing that shaping up over the next quarter or 2?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: That piece is pretty weak right now. A chunk of our heavy manufacturing is tied to is -- easy way to describe it, big wheeled pieces of equipment and that's mining equipment, that's agricultural equipment, it might be military equipment. We have a good fo
componenttext: That piece is pretty weak right now. A chunk of our heavy manufacturing is tied to is -- easy way to describe it, big wheeled pieces of equipment and that's mining equipment, that's agricultural equipment, it might be military equipment. We have a good focus there because those end markets really value what we can bring to their table from the standpoint of fastener expertise and fastener availability as well as everything that goes with it. All those areas are pretty weak right now. You folks know as well as we do what's going on in some of those end markets as far as what some of those large customers are experiencing right now. It's not a pretty picture. And so that's impacting our fastener business because it's impacting our heavy manufacturing.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert McCarthy with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert McCarthy with Stifel.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess one -- this question has been asked prior, but could you could you will walk through, do you think there was any kind of benefit from kind of the roll over and steel from a contract perspective and that's construct how you're thinking about kind o
componenttext: I guess one -- this question has been asked prior, but could you could you will walk through, do you think there was any kind of benefit from kind of the roll over and steel from a contract perspective and that's construct how you're thinking about kind of more of a normalized gross margin at the back half of the year, it's a bit of a leading question so you can argue with the premise of it, that's fine, but I just wanted to ask it.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll answer this way. Deflation and steel never helps our reported margin. It's the steel-based products that are the slowest turning for us. If there is some deflation in non-steel products that we sell, you saw the non-fasteners, that inventory tur
componenttext: Yes. I'll answer this way. Deflation and steel never helps our reported margin. It's the steel-based products that are the slowest turning for us. If there is some deflation in non-steel products that we sell, you saw the non-fasteners, that inventory turns a little bit faster. There you can realize some impact. For us, what we are always endeavoring to do is manage the noise of timing. In, other words, manage where you're getting price concessions, where you're not. And really the only time you ever really can get an impact is you go back to, I think it was 2008 time frame, there was a lot of inflation going on in steel. And we actually saw some short-term gross margin improvement because of it. That was a little unusual because it was so extreme. But generally speaking, we -- the lift -- the improvement we had in gross margin is if there's any impact from steel pricing in there, it's negligible, I'm not sure if it's measurable.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Really, it'll be material?
componenttext: Really, it'll be material?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the second question is, I mean, I know you're reluctant to pull out your crystal ball, just looking at the compares in the back half of the year and some of your comments around nonresidential construction in terms of the fact that oil and gas,
componenttext: Okay. And the second question is, I mean, I know you're reluctant to pull out your crystal ball, just looking at the compares in the back half of the year and some of your comments around nonresidential construction in terms of the fact that oil and gas, I mean, the penumbra or the emanation from oil and gas and the weakness is kind affect more markets than we would like and we would think, how do you think about the -- if you saw a commercial construction recovery or some strife in the back half of this year, the compares, I mean, are the prospects there that you could still see kind of mid- to high single digit organic growth in terms of sale given the acceleration in non-res?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: We believe so. The business really weakened in this 3-month period. We don't know where we are in the weakening cycle. We don't if it's 90% behind us or 50% behind us.
componenttext: We believe so. The business really weakened in this 3-month period. We don't know where we are in the weakening cycle. We don't if it's 90% behind us or 50% behind us.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] where oil is going.
componenttext: [indiscernible] where oil is going.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: What we do know is that, I think we've demonstrated an incredible resiliency to managing through it. And I think the selling energy we've added into our stores gives us a great means to defend anything the market is going to deliver to us. But our folks h
componenttext: What we do know is that, I think we've demonstrated an incredible resiliency to managing through it. And I think the selling energy we've added into our stores gives us a great means to defend anything the market is going to deliver to us. But our folks has always been on, and Lee touched on it really well at the beginning be, being a farm kit, I appreciate that perspective really well. You worry about the things you can effect. I don't worry about the weather when I'm grew up on the farm, but I can't [indiscernible] it. I worry about how I react to it. Same thing here, I don't worry about the economy, but we do focus our energy on how we can react to it. And know that's not a real satisfying answer to your question but largely because we don't frankly, know what the economy is going to deliver in the next 9 to 12 months.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Has -- one more question, I'm sorry, I mean, is there any data points that you're seeing in terms of your order book of your sales has been particularly troubling or that you're really monitoring closely versus just a normal slow down versus a pronounced
componenttext: Has -- one more question, I'm sorry, I mean, is there any data points that you're seeing in terms of your order book of your sales has been particularly troubling or that you're really monitoring closely versus just a normal slow down versus a pronounced cyclical rollover, is there any evidence on one side or the other?

componenttextpreview: No, there's not.
componenttext: No, there's not.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kwame Webb from Morningstar.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kwame Webb from Morningstar.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: So there's been a lot of talk about adding support people to the stores. Maybe you can just to bring us up-to-date on what you've done in terms of headcount additions for the national sales initiative just in terms of adding extra bodies, adding extra IT
componenttext: So there's been a lot of talk about adding support people to the stores. Maybe you can just to bring us up-to-date on what you've done in terms of headcount additions for the national sales initiative just in terms of adding extra bodies, adding extra IT resources just to help us understand a little bit better why that business seems to be growing a lot faster than historically was?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's a case of all the things that we've done. It's a culmination. It's not about what we did in the last 3 months or 6 months or 12 months, it's a culmination. Our store footprint puts us in a position. Picture yourself you have, and last we
componenttext: Yes. I think it's a case of all the things that we've done. It's a culmination. It's not about what we did in the last 3 months or 6 months or 12 months, it's a culmination. Our store footprint puts us in a position. Picture yourself you have, and last week, we had our annual customer showdown in national, Tennessee, I had the opportunity over the course of 3 days to talk to probably more customers than I ever talked to in a 3-day period, which was a wonderful event because what it demonstrated to me is maybe sometimes the realization of how big the opportunity really is and what that means for our ability to grow our business. And so the fact that we positioned ourselves with a great store network, staffed with great people, a distribution and support infrastructure behind the scenes to support the day-to-day activities. Last 5 years, we've built the, basically $0.5 billion a year business selling products through vending machines and all those things support a multilocation customer who wants to have products available for their employees, but doesn't have waste, that's where vending comes in, who wants to have a supplier base that can support them, not in one location or 5 location, but all 20 locations.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, they want consistency.
componenttext: Yes, they want consistency.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and so that's a really important thing. And I think we just, over the years, have gotten better and better at realizing what we bring to the table. And probably at least I can speak for myself, realizing just how massive the opportunity is out there.
componenttext: Yes, and so that's a really important thing. And I think we just, over the years, have gotten better and better at realizing what we bring to the table. And probably at least I can speak for myself, realizing just how massive the opportunity is out there. And that's why I'm a firm believer that business is growing faster because we're underrepresented there, not because these smaller account businesses isn't growing. It's because we're underrepresented in one and we're really poised to sell into that and demonstrate what we can do and take advantage of growth there.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015

componenttext: And I want to say about a year ago I had a conversation with you guys in terms of just making sure that all the incentives were there. I believe there were some commentary saying that you were comfortable paying double commissions both at the store level and at the National Accounts level just to make sure that people weren't competing against each other for businesses, is that still true?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: We believe that it's harder to grow than it is to maintain. We pay a higher commission on growth just like we pay a higher bonus to our non-sales personnel on profit growth than on profit. Because the status quo is easier tan change and we reward for chan
componenttext: We believe that it's harder to grow than it is to maintain. We pay a higher commission on growth just like we pay a higher bonus to our non-sales personnel on profit growth than on profit. Because the status quo is easier tan change and we reward for change.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your question, I believe, though is are we stacking commissions both at nat -- so I'm a National Accounts rep by saying -- yes. Yes, we pay both, but it's much like the national account folks are the hunter but our stores do the work day-to-day to support
componenttext: Your question, I believe, though is are we stacking commissions both at nat -- so I'm a National Accounts rep by saying -- yes. Yes, we pay both, but it's much like the national account folks are the hunter but our stores do the work day-to-day to support the accounts. We pay both and that's factored into our decision and it's a great move. We're all lined up at the company. If the company wins, our employees, our leadership team wins, our support folks win. We don't, we move on.

componenttext: It's coming from everywhere. There's a lot of very, very good local and regional distributors out there. And they have probably 70% of the market. And so just the odds would say they should be getting impacted 70% of the time. And so it's both. But it's a mix.

componenttext: I wanted to follow up on the implications, I guess the cost implications of some of the employee additions you're talking about. headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: The -- if you -- the real driver is looking at that -- those 300 people we're adding every month and the way to think about is we're adding 300 people. They're working, let's just say for discussion sake, 20 hours a week and depending on what the geograph
componenttext: The -- if you -- the real driver is looking at that -- those 300 people we're adding every month and the way to think about is we're adding 300 people. They're working, let's just say for discussion sake, 20 hours a week and depending on what the geography is, our average hourly rate is probably around $11. So that's probably the best way to think about the math, Brent, is kind of those 3 pieces and that's kind of the layering effect we've had on each month going forward as far as the expense.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, I guess, Dan or Lee, the related question is, how do you look at the payback from that? I mean, you're adding -- you're talking about adding basically about 15% FTEs. How productive does that make the other store sellers to get that revenue grow
componenttext: And then, I guess, Dan or Lee, the related question is, how do you look at the payback from that? I mean, you're adding -- you're talking about adding basically about 15% FTEs. How productive does that make the other store sellers to get that revenue growth and gross profit dollar to offset or even to get a decent return on those part-time additions?

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: It doesn't take a lot of business to get payback on that type of expense when you spread it across 100-and-some thousand dollar store. But what it does provide is the employee base that we have in that store, and I'm talking about the salespeople that we
componenttext: It doesn't take a lot of business to get payback on that type of expense when you spread it across 100-and-some thousand dollar store. But what it does provide is the employee base that we have in that store, and I'm talking about the salespeople that we have in the stores, the seasoned salespeople, that's [indiscernible] in expensive population. But more importantly, it's a very productive population, but if they're coming in everyday to help receive in the truck or to make deliveries, it just -- it removes from their day, from their window the pure amount of time to get out and sell and again, as I touched on in the earlier question about opportunity, opportunity is staggering. I still visit a lot of stores, and I'm always amazed by just one -- when I ask people in the store where's -- what are some of the customers or what are some of the opportunities in this market. The opportunities are staggering. And we want to be able to unleash that because this cost at the end of the day on a store-by-store basis, because if you look at it, we have around 2,600, 2,700 stores, we're really talking about doesn't take a lot of revenue dollars and gross profit dollars to pay for that and get a pretty attractive return because all your other expenses in the store is fixed.

headline: Fastenal Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Brent, I would just jump in. When you add a part-timer, now I'm going back to my days in the store, when you add a part-timer into a store where you have a General Manager and OSP and a team that understands the value they bring to the market and they
componenttext: And Brent, I would just jump in. When you add a part-timer, now I'm going back to my days in the store, when you add a part-timer into a store where you have a General Manager and OSP and a team that understands the value they bring to the market and they can actually present that more often, the return on that part-timer is hard to measure. But Dan's really touching on a lot of things. We have opportunity within current customers. We saw that last week in Nashville. But we need to be out in the market daily taking market share. And that's what this part-time employee brings, not only, but it's the other side of the coin, is the part-timer gets to understand our company and our culture to make a decision long-term for them. It's a win-win for both the employee coming in and for our teams in the store.
